370796: Dismiss into Dream.author: sarroth
370796: Dismiss into Dream.text_parsed:
@volkiteSerpenta: No it doesn't. Overload replaces targeting with instead hitting everything. Thus overload doesn't target.

Despite this not working with overload, it is still ridiculously amazing. Even without pingers and other targeting effects, it shuts down equipment and auras save for your opponent cheating them in and shuts down secondary effects on removal (e.g., losing life to a Phthisis). Really expensive, sure, but that's because it would be close to broken otherwise. Certainly fun for the one controlling it, that's for sure.

370798: Path of Bravery.author: infernox10
370798: Path of Bravery.text_parsed:
I actually really enjoy this card more than other anthems.
Obviously, the lifegain on attacking is the major upside that you're meant to consider.
However, this makes calculating a nightmare for your opponent, and this is the factor that makes me most interested in it.
Your opponent needs to be keeping seriously good track of what he or she is trading with, what he or she is willing to swing into, etc.
All it takes is one hasty creature or Instant lifegain to totally blow out a presumed "safe" alpha-swing.
370798: Path of Bravery.text_posted:

370798: Path of Bravery.author: Aremath
370798: Path of Bravery.text_parsed: I really like the whole "starting life total" rules text. Makes it more fair in EDH and 2HG. Overall, it's really interesting. While Honor of the Pure and Glorious Anthem are both more consistent in terms of the pump, if you have a lot of creatures, the lifegain will actually help a lot. It ends up causing interesting decisions, so while both of the above are more 'playable' in a spikey sense, I think that this card is definitely more interesting.

370800: Corpse Hauler.author: majinara
370800: Corpse Hauler.text_parsed:
Ok in limited, sucks otherwise. The main problem is the mana cost of its activated ability. Normally, you want to sacrifice such creatures in respond to removal. "You want to shock my guy? I sac him in response". But it's very unlikely that a black deck has three mana around at all times for that.

It's also just too expensive in general. A raise dead does the same and costs one mana instead of a total of five, that you have to pay here for the effect.

I'd always play cadavre imp over this. Only two power, but it does the whole job for three mana and can keep attacking, with evasion, while you already got the card back from the gy. Gravedigger is superior too. Costs two more, but is in total still cheaper than this guy, and you always get the creature card back (unlike this guy, which, when killed when you have no three mana around, doesn't give you anything). And it's also a zombie, so it gets buffed from all sorts of zombie cards.

So, 1.5/5 from me, for a crappy gravedigger.

I'd expect that it is hard to find people who are willing to desecrate graves and haul corpses, so why is he willing to destroy this valuable asset? This isn't a question of goodness, it's a simply a question of practicality! Also, secondly, why is his blade made out of silver? That's a really bad, not to mention expensive, metal to make a weapon out of, and it's definitely not a good idea to use it against anything other than a werewolf or similar.

370801: Bonescythe Sliver.author: FelixCarter
370801: Bonescythe Sliver.text_parsed:
@Gandlodder
Actually, I think the "you control" effect was merely added for the sake of new players. As this is a core set, having a new person only worry about how to buff their creatures is a lot nicer than finding out they just buffed their opponent's creatures as well. Having been a new player myself, I can totally understand this. But don't worry; I doubt we've seen the last of global effects outside of core sets. :3

As for the card, the design is very competitive and will be appearing in many sliver decks to come... Kinsbaile Cavalier was usually just a 4/2, essentially. But by the time this guy arrives, your hive is already adding more power to him. Add on the fact that he only serves your board position, and the effect is deadly. Fury Sliver will still have a home for singleton and EDH decks, as well as people who prefer to stay pure and true to the old-fashion slivers.

I always feel it's hit or miss with Trevor Claxton's work. Sometimes I really like his art style, and sometimes I feel he could have used less darker or lighter values. However I'm a little on the fence with this one. On one hand, I'm loving the focus he brings to the slivers scythe-like arm. The perspective and foreshortening of the creature is superbly done. Depth of field mixed with light values in the background really helps the shadow and darker values in the foreground leap out. On the other hand, however, I'm not entirely a fan of the shadows used on the canyon walls so close to the sliver. I feel it really distorts the outline of its figure and maybe wasn't needed. Also, I would have liked to see more detail on how it's balancing in that stance. Is it lurking slowly forward, or are we seeing it advancing quickly to its destination? Even then, Trevor has done a good job.

370806: Witchstalker.author: Ferlord
370806: Witchstalker.text_parsed:
If you don't play limited, this won't apply to you as much. Otherwise, please keep reading.

There are two different types of spells: Questions and Answers.

Questions are things that pose a problem. Things like Rumbling Baloth or Regathan Firecat are questions. All creatures are technically questions. Creatures with higher power are questions that should be answered quickly, while creatures with higher toughness are harder to answer. Creatures with both are generally good creatures (Baloth is a harder question to answer than Firecat for obvious reasons).

Answers are things that solve problems. Things like Essence Scatter and Chandra's Outrage are great answers. They solve questions so you can then ask them a question later on.

Imagine each time you play a spell, you ask them, "Can you solve this?". If it makes sense ("Can you solve this Capashen Knight?"), then it's a question. If it doesn't, ("Can you solve this Disperse?") then it's more of an answer.

If you give your deck too many answers and not enough questions, you will have answers without purpose. You will be waiting for questions, or you won't have the right answer for the question at the time (there are only so many answers you can draft that solve many questions).

A good limited deck has lots of questions and some answers. If you keep asking them questions, they'll be so overwhelmed that they'll be unable to stop you. They'll have to use their questions to answer your questions. You'll have an easier time because you won't have as many questions to solve.

Some questions are obviously harder to answer. Mark of the Vampire is one of the best questions you could ask in limited because it provides a problem while also solving an important question (gaining you life, saving you from death).

Other questions like Serra Angel are also great because it's both a hard question to answer and a good answer to questions (it's a big creature with evasion and a means to stop evasion which can attack and block).

This here is a good question because it's almost impossible to answer. The more time you answer questions, the more dangerous this becomes. There are very few ways to answer the Hexproof question.

So, for those who don't like reading (that's fine: I know I wrote a lot), what I'd like people to take out of this is that limited is a format where having lots of problems to solve is a good thing. If you have too many ways to stop problems and not enough problems that need solving, you won't do so well.
370806: Witchstalker.text_posted:
[u][i]If you don't play limited, this won't apply to you as much. Otherwise, please keep reading.[/i][/u]

There are two different types of spells: [u][b]Questions and Answers[/b][/u].

[u]Questions[/u] are things that pose a problem. Things like [autocard]Rumbling Baloth[/autocard] or [autocard]Regathan Firecat[/autocard] are questions. All creatures are technically questions. Creatures with higher power are questions that should be answered quickly, while creatures with higher toughness are harder to answer. Creatures with both are generally good creatures (Baloth is a harder question to answer than Firecat for obvious reasons).

[u]Answers[/u] are things that solve [i]problems[/i]. Things like [autocard]Essence Scatter[/autocard] and [autocard]Chandra's Outrage[/autocard] are great answers. They solve questions so you can then ask them a question later on. 

Imagine each time you play a spell, you ask them, [b]"Can you solve this?"[/b]. If it makes sense ("Can you solve this [autocard]Capashen Knight[/autocard]?"), then it's a question. If it doesn't, ("Can you solve this [autocard]Disperse[/autocard]?") then it's more of an answer. 

If you give your deck too many answers and not enough questions, you will have answers without purpose. You will be waiting for questions, or you won't have the right answer for the question at the time (there are only so many answers you can draft that solve many questions).

A good limited deck has lots of questions and some answers. If you keep asking them questions, they'll be so overwhelmed that they'll be unable to stop you. They'll have to use their questions to answer your questions. You'll have an easier time because you won't have as many questions to solve.

Some questions are obviously harder to answer. [autocard]Mark of the Vampire[/autocard] is one of the best questions you could ask in limited because it provides a problem while also solving an important question (gaining you life, saving you from death). 

Other questions like [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] are also great because it's both a hard question to answer and a good answer to questions (it's a big creature with evasion and a means to stop evasion which can attack and block).

This here is a good question because it's almost impossible to answer. The more time you answer questions, the more dangerous this becomes. There are very few ways to answer the Hexproof question.

So, for those who don't like reading (that's fine: I know I wrote a lot), what I'd like people to take out of this is that limited is a format where having lots of problems to solve is a good thing. 370810: Windreader Sphinx.author: DarthParallax
370810: Windreader Sphinx.text_parsed:
It's the Ultimate Ophidian/Scroll Thief style card. Essentially, it gives that ability to your whole battlefield, by asking that your whole battlefield be made up of creatures with evasion.

For a Mythic, I expect just a little bit more. Like for it to give my creatures with power 3 or less Flying, or something (Drakify them?) Or else to have better attack stats. 4/7? 5/8? It's a good card. I think it would have been alright at Rare, which makes it seem odd that it's Mythic. It's Powerful sure.

Let me finish with this though: I think that for some unique types of cards, particularly anything that could be compared to either Consecrated Sphinx or the Titans for any reason- It's probably good for the game that occasionally we get cards at Mythic Rare that could make sense at Rare. For the most part I think this applies to Value Creatures.

Compare Archangel's Light to Time Reversal to Domesticate to Lord of the Pit to Serra Angel to Shivan Dragon to Windreader Sphinx to COLOSSAL WHALE.

Trying to take all of these cards in, and how their 'epicness' either showed or didn't show, I feel one just has to conclude that Creature spells be given more leeway to just be considered Epicer, but that Non-Creature Spells DO need to be graded pretty hard on whether they 'felt' Mythic or not.

Colossal Whale is far away the Most Mythic of them all, yet What if he were a 3/3 for 5 mana? Almost Okay at Uncommon? I do not care, with that Art he'd still be in the same "Mythicness" category as Time Reversal to Flavor Savorers. Whereas most people don't like the Rarity of Domesticate and NOBODY likes the Mythicness of Archangel's Light.

Let me finish with this though: I think that for some unique types of cards, particularly anything that could be compared to either Consecrated Sphinx or the Titans for any reason- It's probably good for the game that occasionally we get cards at Mythic Rare that could make sense at Rare. For the most part I think this applies to Value Creatures.

Compare [autocard]Archangel's Light[/autocard] to [autocard]Time Reversal[/autocard] to [autocard]Domesticate[/autocard] to [autocard]Lord of the Pit[/autocard] to [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] to [autocard]Shivan Dragon[/autocard] to Windreader Sphinx to [autocard]COLOSSAL WHALE[/autocard]. 

Trying to take all of these cards in, and how their 'epicness' either showed or didn't show, I feel one just has to conclude that Creature spells be given more leeway to just be considered Epicer, but that Non-Creature Spells DO need to be graded pretty hard on whether they 'felt' Mythic or not. 

Colossal Whale is far away the Most Mythic of them all, yet What if he were a 3/3 for 5 mana? Almost Okay at Uncommon? I do not care, with that Art he'd still be in the same "Mythicness" category as Time Reversal to Flavor Savorers. Whereas most people don't like the Rarity of Domesticate and NOBODY likes the Mythicness of Archangel's Light.

370810: Windreader Sphinx.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
370810: Windreader Sphinx.text_parsed:
@Riandro: What Strionic Resonator copies are abilities on the stack, not lines of text on permanents. When flying creatures attack, the Sphinx gives you one "You may draw a card" ability for each. You may copy only one of these with the Resonator, unfortunately you won't double the amount of draw. (I rated your comment down not because it was a bad question, but to answer no. If a question is rated high enough to be on the first page, I think most people assume the answer is yes.)

@DarthParallax: You missed two important details.

Unlike Ophidian, the flyer need not be unblocked. You will get the cards immediately when they are declared as attackers. You can send them on kamikaze attacks if you want.

And most importantly, any flyer will give you a card. It's not only good at making your flyers more awesome, it makes your opponent think twice about attacking. In a multiplayer game, even flyers attacking other people will give you more card draw. That's much more mythic, isn't it?

It's weird that they chose that art yet again. It's instantly recognizable, i'll give it that.
And by now somewhat nostalgic for some people as well, me included.

In general, i prefer it when a consistent reprint keeps the old artwork (in Core Sets and Duel Decks, at least) instead of getting a new artwork over and over again.

Yet i agree, Marilyn "Grakk" Manson and his armed cartoon mouse ("armed" as in "body parts") could use a break.

I can see why they wouldn't want to use the one with Akroma (or the one with Karn) in M14.
I don't know why they never use the 7th Edition one. It's the most straight-forward take on Pacifism.

But, you know, they could also just have one of their artists make a new artwork.
Which they can use for the next ten Core Sets.

370814: Voracious Wurm.author: Ferlord
370814: Voracious Wurm.text_parsed:
Kind of like a reverse Ajani's Pridemate, this is a decent creature. I don't think it'll see much competitive play, though.

Since you need to play another spell or activated another ability beforehand, it adds to the line of things to do that can (and will) be stopped. It's like you're playing a combo deck. If someone counters one of the three spells you need to play to win, then the whole plan fails.

Ajani's Pridemate, on the other hand, could be played as is doesn't require a spell to be played immediately beforehand. It is true that playing Soul Warden before it is a good idea, but it's not required to make it good. You could play Pridemate, then play Kitchen Finks.

Also, as others have mentioned, it's not White. You'd have to splash Green in your Soul Sisters deck to play this. Although you can play Essence Warden, Martyr of Sands would get chumped (mind you, Martyr would do wonders with this...).

370814: Voracious Wurm.author: xlebec
370814: Voracious Wurm.text_parsed: I found the trickiest thing in constructing a lifegain deck was being able to keep offensive pressure on the opponent while still gaining a meaningful amount of life to protect myself. While I certainly wouldn't want to rely on this guy for my win condition, he generally helps fill out that offensive role quite nicely, and as a bonus he occasionally hits the field as a 9/9 on turn 3 or a 16/16 on turn 5. I don't know if he'll be as potentially useful late game once Rhox Faithmender rotates out, but even without those combos he still seems pretty solid and fun to play.

370814: Voracious Wurm.author: Ataraxiom
370814: Voracious Wurm.text_parsed:
I'm amazed to see that this card is debuting in the M14 Core Set, the design just feels too good for it to have not been used already.

I love this card because it can be a significant play at any point in the game.

Early game? Tap your Soulmender and drop this guy as a 3/3 on turn 2.

Mid game? Bust up your opponent's stuff with a Solemn Offering and get yourself a 6/6.

Late game? Roll off of an Alive // Well and watch your 2/2 hit the field as a 12/12.

The applications are endless, and this little wurm can quickly find friends in the M14 Core Set. Angelic Accord, Archangel of Thune, Path of Bravery, and Brindle Boar all say hi!

370815: Warden of Evos Isle.author: Kaizeischi
370815: Warden of Evos Isle.text_parsed:
Would anyone else agree that cards like this are a step toward slowing down Standard? Not that it's a bad thing, but I feel like Wizards realized how fast everything was getting and decided to move toward slower board-presence deck construction.

Reasonably, flyers cost slightly more than their land counterparts simply because of their evasive abilities (or are weaker, either way). I'm wondering if Wizards is pushing flyers so much in this set (Windreader Sphinx?) because they know that it will not only slow everything down a tad, but that they'll combo well with the enchantment-heavy set coming out. This card alone can make us think, "That guy's expensive... but NOT if I play 4x Warden!"

Just a thought. Any opinions/support?

370816: Brave the Elements.author: Golem_Token
370816: Brave the Elements.text_parsed:
I have to say I think this card is seriously underrated at the moment. Currently rated 3.5 for M14, but 4.2 on the zendikar printing.

This card is so relevant in standard right now. BtE can essentially make all your creatures unblockable until end of turn on your turn, protect your creatures from direct/mass damage, or act as a pseudo-hexproof mechanic. All that for 1 mana, instantly.

Mizzium Mortars? Nope. Anger of the Gods? Nope. Rapid Hybridization? Nope Disperse? Nope. Detention Sphere? Nope. Banisher Priest? Nope Dreadbore? Nope. Hero's Downfall? Nope. Doom Blade Nope. Bile Blight? Nope.

That list was off the top of my head, and most of those spells have a CMC greater than 1. There's just so many spells that get shut down by this.

For me, there are 2 big drawbacks to the card. You need creatures on the board for the card to be relevant. The second, bigger drawback is that said creatures need to be white. Having said that, white has a lot of great weenie creatures in standard right now. Heck, this card is great for G/W aggro. Dryad Militant, Loxodon Smiter, Fleecemane Lion, Voice of Resurgence, AND the VoR tokens love this card!

4 / 5

370817: Hive Stirrings.author: FelixCarter
370817: Hive Stirrings.text_parsed:
Colorless Sliver token:
http://browse.deviantart.com/art/Token-385386192

The card is a very interesting flashback to Join the Ranks. I think everyone can agree that Allies were very similar to slivers (except they used triggered instead of passive abilities), and this card crosses that bridge. Comparatively, I don't think the sorcery speed diminishes the power, due to being less. This will give any hive two more slivers that can either be beastly themselves or completely expendable to use the abilities you wanted to hold on to. I would have liked to see this be a tribal spell, but - as this is a core set - I can understand why this was impossible. Great card.

The art is very impressive, and does a good job of bridging the gap in terms of the question, "Where's the missing sliver link?" The slivery heads and mantis-like arms gives the feel of the old slivers we once knew while staying close to the ones we now see. I'm loving the silhouette effect Maciej Kuciara decided to go with. The bight light mixed with hanging shadows gives an eerie, inhuman effect that slivers deserve. Amazing details and strong effects makes this a card you'll want to admire before casting.

370819: Blessing.author: DarthParallax
370819: Blessing.text_parsed:
3 stars, and almost breaking 4! If you're a NON-CREATURE getting a 3.5 10 years later, you are Looking Fine B|

Even though the creatures get more easily Power Creeped into obsoleteness, they also have 'Faceness', 'Icon' going for them, like Shivan Dragon, Lord of the Pit, Leviathan, and Serra Angel do. Even weird sets like Arabian Nights whose most notable cards are some broken uncommon lands....we still remember Juzam Djinn very well, don't we?

It takes quite a bit to come down through the ages if you're a non-creature spell, because you usually either got banned, or 8th Edition said you were too good for reprinting. And of those that remain, a lot of them are....well, kind of weak. Really I think Wrath of God is the only Rare that will always belong in Magic and always feel Rare, no matter how many names they give it...

Blessing itself is weird but cool, because it really asks a whole lot of color-commitment to White Mana...Green, Red, and Black tend to care about that kind of thing more, White and Blue tend to be more splashable.

370819: Blessing.author: blurrymadness
370819: Blessing.text_parsed:
White tends not to have the mana it takes to make this brutal efficient, but it's still a good little card none-the-less; especially because white does reliably *get* it's mana (tithe, land tax, etc..) so if the game goes long, you'll be able to turn a weenie into something huge; at least big enough to pummel your opponent.

People complain about auras, but honestly the time in the game that this comes down (probably later so you can give a lot to it) people don't necessarily have removal on hand. Plus! You're white; you have protection spells silly! Now feed your little soldier a bunch of donuts and clobber someone.

370825: Shivan Dragon.author: Ferlord
370825: Shivan Dragon.text_parsed:
Just to put things into perspective, this used to cost $25/ea.

I learned of this because this guy who plays at my comic store used to play around 3rd edition. He had a playset of these and was playing against a friend of his. He wasn't competitive, but he still paid $25 for them.

Regardless, he played his first one, but it got countered by Counterspell, as Rabbimoshie mentioned.
He played his second. Countered again.
He played his third. Countered again.
He draws his fourth. "Ok buddy" he said. "If you have another god-damned Counterspell in your hand, I'm going to eat this".
The other guy countered the last Dragon, thinking he wouldn't seriously eat something that was $25.

He then ate the most expensive piece of cardboard he's ever eaten.

370825: Shivan Dragon.author: DarthParallax
370825: Shivan Dragon.text_parsed:
I do not really LIKE saying this, as a rather old gamer I'm very attached to Nostalgia. (24, and tbh, this game is intended to be accessible to 13 yr olds. This usually puts off everyone older than 16 that plays. :/ )

But Truth be told, this card is...powerful, but weak. For "Constructed" play, it's practically no better than many commons. For Sealed Deck or Limited, it certainly IS a win-condition, and *5* toughness is really tough to beat...but at the same time, every color has good ways to kill it. It has absolutely zero protection from removal, not a single clause or condition on it's abilities prevent it from dying to even the narrowest of removal spells.....EXCEPT for red cards that can't hit flying creatures ala Earthquake, but those cards are very often used as Lava Axes anyway.

Therefore, even though it WOULD make it incredibly powerful, it would DEFINITELY be a mark of Power Creep, it would be .... in a lot of ways, one of very very few curtains left to fall on the Ancient Days of MAGIC....this needs


to become an Uncommon. It would Change Core Set Limited certainly, but not break it. Rather, it would just make the card Relevant without giving you the bad feels that it ate your Rare slot. It would be a good solution to Powerful Bombs that other players get in their Mythic and Rare slots. It's probably not anymore ''broken'' than Doom Blade in Limited, and Doom Blade is justly at Uncommon right now. AND

Serra Angel as an Uncommon and this as a Rare feels wrong. They should be together, they are very similar in power, just different in use.

Right now, I don't think many people play this in Limited, simply because it's first of all at Rare so not many people pull it in Limited, and second because Uncommons and Mythics together tend to fill the different roles you could want this card for, only do it better.

370825: Shivan Dragon.author: Joseph_Silver
370825: Shivan Dragon.text_parsed:
While this iconic critter is nowhere as viable in Constructed today as it was in the early years of Magic, it still remains a very powerful bomb in Limited. Just yesterday, I won an M14 draft with Shivan Dragon. I delayed casting it until I felt that my opponent was out of removal, and it won me the game each time it resolved throughout the entire draft. That draft basically paid for itself thanks to this iconic red fattie.

Remember, folks, most cards are made for Limited. If it seems worthless in a Constructed deck, it may be very powerful in Limited.
